instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message:
Good morning , this mac had oxidation close to Smc, more precisely <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> replaces it, I did reball in SMC and used another BIOS dump and another BIOS chip, but nothing solved it. 


Voltage: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.6V; <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.49V; <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> is oscillating, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> oscillating between 0 and 3v when the cooler turns.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message:
VCORE pulses too?
Did you check <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/03?

Try to start in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0v, pulseless.
<RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR>/02 180K and 150K.
<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pin 1 12.37v; pin 2 12.41V;

The cooler is no longer rotating.
It does not accept SMC deviation.
Substitutes SMC, but no result.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS at least?
Post any S3/0 voltage, if you get any.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message:
So you get pulsing S3, even S0 voltages.
Check them all: big coils and pages 71/72.
Any pulse at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message:
L7030 12.72V
L7260 0V, oscillating 4.65V
L7220 3.33V
L7330 0.13V, oscillating 1.14V
L7760 0V, oscillating 1.71V
L7770 0v, oscillating 1.06V


<SIGNAL>PP3V3_ENET_PHY</SIGNAL> 0v, oscillating 3.16V
<SIGNAL>P1V8S0_COMP</SIGNAL> 0v, oscillating .70V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> .16V, oscillating .94V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0v, oscillating 3.18V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> .89V, oscillating 3.04V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.01V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 0v, oscillating 1.47V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0v, oscillating 2.92V

replaces <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> because when I apply voltage to the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> mesh the component heats up but still has the same defect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message:
any idea of can be?  oxidation under the PCH?  <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> with some bad terminal or other component?
is there any point that i can apply voltage and identify the defective component?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message: Try to heat PCH, with quality flux; no more than 180-200 degrees, 15-20s.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message: Maybe not worth to continue with this board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message: But are these tensions that I pass on to you on page 71/72 normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message: I would like to know why I have to analyze page 71/72 ? Which different values do you have to give to see that some component is defective? What if it was to reball or change which chip could be the PCH or CPU defect ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> rotates the cooler and to
threads.message:
You've posted some voltages and I asked you to check more.
Maybe other voltages don't pulse at all.
